title: The Merchant's Decision
subtitle: If/Else Branching
description:
# Making Choices with Else

You've learned if statements, but what happens when the condition is False? That's where **else** comes in!

## If/Else Structure

The else block runs when the if condition is False:

```python
gold = 30
item_cost = 50

if gold >= item_cost:
    print("Purchase successful!")
    gold = gold - item_cost
else:
    print("Not enough gold!")
```

One of these blocks will ALWAYS run - either if or else.

## Comparison Operators

Python supports many comparison operators:

```python
==  # Equal to
!=  # Not equal to
>   # Greater than
<   # Less than
>=  # Greater than or equal to
<=  # Less than or equal to
```

## Your Quest

Create a merchant system that checks if a player can afford an item:
1. Set player's gold amount
2. Set item cost
3. Use if/else to check if player has enough gold
4. If yes: Print success message and show remaining gold
5. If no: Print how much more gold is needed

solutionCode:
# Merchant Purchase System

# Set up variables
player_gold = 75
item_cost = 50
item_name = "Steel Sword"

# Check if player can afford the item
if player_gold >= item_cost:
    # Player has enough gold
    remaining_gold = player_gold - item_cost
    print(f"Purchase successful! You bought {item_name}.")
    print(f"Gold remaining: {remaining_gold}")
else:
    # Player doesn't have enough gold
    gold_needed = item_cost - player_gold
    print(f"Not enough gold for {item_name}!")
    print(f"You need {gold_needed} more gold.")
hints: The condition should check if player_gold >= item_cost
In the if block, calculate remaining_gold = player_gold - item_cost

    print(f'Not enough gold for {item_name}!')
